text: In the third year of the reign of King Jehoiakim of Judah, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came to Jerusalem and laid siege to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within a week, the Lord handed King Jehoiakim of Judah over to him, along with valuable objects from the house of God. Nebuchadnezzar brought them to the temple of his god in the land of Shinar and stored them in its treasure house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the king ordered Ashpenaz, his chief officer, to bring in some Israelis of royal and noble descent.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were to be young men without physical defect, handsome in appearance, skilled in all wisdom, quick to learn, prudent in how they used knowledge, and capable of serving in the king’s palace. They were to learn the literature and language of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king assigned them fine food and choice wine on a daily basis, ordering them to be trained for three years, at the end of which time they would enter the king’s service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Included among the people of Judah were Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief officer assigned the name “Belteshazzar” to Daniel, the name “Shadrach” to Hananiah, the name “Meshach” to Mishael, and the name “Abednego” to Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel determined within himself not to become defiled by the king’s menu of rich foods or by the king’s wine, so he requested permission from the chief officer not to defile himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: God granted to Daniel grace and compassion on the part of the chief officer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief officer told Daniel, “I fear his majesty the king, who has determined what you eat and drink. If he notices that your faces are more pale than the other young men in your group, I will forfeit my head to the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Daniel told the guard whom the chief officer had appointed over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please test your servants for ten days and let us be given vegetables to eat and water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then compare how we look with the young men who ate the king’s rich food, and treat your servants in accordance with what you observe.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he listened to what Daniel said and tested them for ten days.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of ten days their appearance was better and their faces were well-nourished compared to the young men who ate the king’s rich food.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the guard took away their rich food and wine, giving them vegetables.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for these four young men, God gave them knowledge, aptitude for learning, and wisdom. Daniel also could understand all kinds of visions and dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at the end of the training period that the king had established, the chief officer brought them in before Nebuchadnezzar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king spoke to them, none of them compared to Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, or Azariah as they stood before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every matter of wisdom or understanding that the king discussed with them, he found them ten times superior to all the astrologers and enchanters in his entire palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Daniel remained there in service until the first year of King Cyrus.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the second year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign, Nebuchadnezzar had dreams that troubled him. As a result, he couldn’t sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king gave orders to summon diviners, enchanters, sorcerers, and Chaldeans to reveal to the king what he had dreamed. When they came and stood before him,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king told them, “I have dreamed a dream and I will remain troubled until I can understand it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Chaldeans responded to the king in Aramaic: “May the king live forever. Tell the dream to your servants, and we’ll reveal its meaning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In reply the king told the Chaldeans, “Here is what I have commanded: If you don’t tell me both the dream and its meaning, you’ll be destroyed and your houses will be reduced to rubble.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do relate the dream to me as well as its meaning, you’ll receive gifts, rewards, and great honor from me. Therefore reveal the dream to me, along with its meaning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied again, “Let the king tell his servants the dream, and we’ll disclose its meaning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king responded, “I’m convinced that you’re stalling for time because you’re aware of what I’ve commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you don’t disclose the dream to me, there will be only one sentence for all of you. You have conspired together to present lies and corrupt interpretations until the situation changes. Now tell me the dream and I’ll know that you can reveal its true meaning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Chaldeans answered the king directly, “There’s not a single man on earth who can do what the king has commanded. No king, lord, or ruler has ever asked such a thing from any diviner, enchanter, or Chaldean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, what the king is asking is so difficult that no one can reveal it except the gods—and they don’t live with human beings.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, the king flew into a rage and issued an order to destroy all the advisors of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the order went out to kill the advisors, they searched for Daniel and his friends to kill them, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel responded with wisdom and discretion to Arioch, the king’s executioner, who had gone out to execute the advisors of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked him, “Why such a harsh decree from the king?” Then Arioch informed Daniel,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Daniel went to ask Nebuchadnezzar for an appointment to see him, and it was granted him so that he could reveal the meaning to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel went home and told his friends Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah about the king’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel was seeking mercy, in order to ask about this mystery in the presence of the God of heaven, so that Daniel and his friends might not be executed along with the rest of the advisors of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision later that night, Daniel blessed the God of heaven
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
It is God who alters the times and seasons,
    and he removes kings and promotes kings.
He gives wisdom to the wise
    and knowledge to the discerning.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
To you, God of my ancestors, I give thanks and praise,
    because you have given me wisdom and power;
you have now revealed to me what we asked of you
    by making known to us what the king commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Daniel went to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to execute the advisors of Babylon. He told him, “Don’t destroy the advisors of Babylon. Bring me before the king and I’ll explain the meaning to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Arioch quickly brought Daniel into the king’s presence and informed him: “I’ve found a man from the Judean captives who will make known the meaning to the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar replied by saying to Daniel (whose Babylonian name is Belteshazzar), “Are you able to tell me about the dream and its meaning?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
By way of answer, Daniel addressed the king:
“None of the advisors, enchanters, diviners, or astrologers can explain the secret that the king has requested to be made known.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a God in heaven who reveals secrets, and he is making known to King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen in the latter days.
“While you were in bed, the dream and the visions that came to your head were as follows:
speaker: Narrator

text: Your majesty, when you were in bed, thoughts came to your mind about what would happen in the future, and the Revealer of Secrets has made known to you what will take place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, this secret was made known to me, not because my own wisdom is greater than anyone else alive, but in order that the meaning may be made known to the king, and that you might understand the thoughts of your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your majesty, while you were watching, you observed an enormous statue. This magnificent statue stood before you with extraordinary brilliance. Its appearance was terrifying.
speaker: Narrator

text: That statue had a head made of pure gold, with its chest and arms made of silver, its abdomen and thighs made of bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: its legs made of iron, and its feet made partly of iron and partly of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As you were watching, a rock was quarried—but not with human hands—and it struck the iron and clay feet of the statue, breaking them to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were broken in pieces together and became like chaff from a summer threshing floor that the breeze carries away without leaving a trace. Then the rock that struck the statue grew into a huge mountain and filled the entire earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This was the dream, and we’ll now relate its meaning to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, your majesty, king of kings—to whom the God of heaven has given the kingdom, the power, the strength, and the glory,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that wherever people, wild animals, or birds of the sky live, he has placed them under your control, giving you dominion over them all—you’re that head of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After you, another kingdom will arise that is inferior to yours, and then a third kingdom of bronze will arise to rule all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there will be a fourth kingdom, as strong as iron. Just as all things are broken to pieces and shattered by iron, so it will shatter and crush everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The feet and toes that you saw, made partly of potter’s clay and partly of iron, represent a divided kingdom. It will still have the strength of iron, in that you saw iron mixed with clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as their toes and feet are part iron and part clay, so will the kingdom be both strong and brittle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as you saw iron mixed with clay, so they will mix themselves with human offspring. Furthermore, they won’t remain together, just as iron doesn’t mix with clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: “During the reigns of those kings, the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that will never be destroyed, nor its sovereignty left in the hands of another people. It will shatter and crush all of these kingdoms, and it will stand forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, just as you saw that the stone was cut out of the mountain without human hands—and that it crushed the iron, bronze, clay, silver, and gold to pieces—so also the great God has revealed to the king what will take place after this. Your dream will come true, and its meaning will prove trustworthy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell on his face before Daniel, paid honor to him, and commanded that an offering and incense be presented on his behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king told Daniel, “Truly your God is the God of gods, the Lord of kings, and the Revealer of Secrets, because you were able to reveal this mystery.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king promoted Daniel to a high position and lavished many great gifts on him, including making him ruler over the entire province of Babylon and chief administrator over the advisors of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Daniel requested that the king appoint Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego administrators over the province of Babylon, while Daniel himself remained in the royal court.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, king Nebuchadnezzar built a golden statue, making it 60 cubits high and six cubits wide. He set it up in the Dura Valley within the province of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar summoned the regional authorities, governors, deputy governors, advisors, treasurers, judges, magistrates, and all of the other administrators of the provinces, ordering them to come to the dedication of the statue that he had erected.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the regional authorities, governors, deputy governors, advisors, treasurers, judges, magistrates, and all of the other administrators of the provinces assembled to dedicate the statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had erected. They took their places in front of the statue that he had erected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a herald proclaimed aloud:
“People of all nations, and languages are commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever you hear the sound of the trumpet, the flute, the lyre, the four-stringed lyre, and the harp, playing together along with various instruments, you are to fall down and worship the golden statue that was set up by King Nebuchadnezzar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who does not fall down and worship is immediately to be thrown into the blazing fire furnace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when all of the people “heard the sound of the trumpet, the flute, the lyre, the four-stringed lyre, and the harp, playing together along with various other instruments,” all the “people, nations, and languages” began to fall down and worship the golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, certain influential Chaldeans took this opportunity to come forward and denounce the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told King Nebuchadnezzar, “Your majesty, live forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, your majesty, issued this decree:
‘Every man who hears the sound of the trumpet, the flute, the lyre, the four-stringed lyre, and the harp, playing together along with various other instruments is to fall down and worship the golden statue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever does not fall down and worship is to be thrown into a blazing fire furnace.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Certain influential Jewish men whom you appointed to manage the city of Babylon—Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego—have neither paid attention to you, your majesty, nor served your gods. And they won’t worship the golden statue that you set up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar flew into a rage and furiously ordered that Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego be brought before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar asked them, “Is it true, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, that you don’t worship my gods and that you don’t worship the golden statue that has been set up?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, if you are ready at this very moment to obey ‘the sound of the trumpet, the flute, the lyre, the four-stringed lyre, and the harp,’ and worship the image that I have made… If you do not so worship, you will immediately have cast yourselves into the middle of the blazing fire, and what god is there who can deliver you from my power?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego answered King Nebuchadnezzar, “It’s not necessary for us to respond in this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your majesty, if it be his will, our God whom we serve can deliver us from the blazing fire furnace, and he will deliver us from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if not, rest assured, your majesty, that we won’t serve your gods, and we won’t worship the golden statue that you have set up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of control with rage, Nebuchadnezzar’s facial expression changed toward Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, and he ordered that the furnace be heated seven times hotter than usual.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he issued orders to his elite guard to bind Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego with ropes and throw them into the blazing fire furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the elite guard tied them up fully clothed, still wearing their robes, tunics, and turbans, and threw them into the blazing fire furnace,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the king’s command was so drastic. Since the furnace was blazing hot, its flames killed those who threw Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego into the blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bound firmly with ropes, these three men Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego fell into the blazing fire furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Astonished, King Nebuchadnezzar stood up in terror, and asked his advisors, “Didn’t we throw three men into the fire, bound firmly with ropes?”
In reply they told the king, “Yes, your majesty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” he told them, “I see four men walking untied and unharmed in the middle of the fire, and the appearance of the fourth resembles a divine being.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nebuchadnezzar approached the opening of the blazing fire furnace. He shouted out, “Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, servants of the Most High God, come out and come here!” So Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego came out of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The regional authorities, viceroys, governors, and royal advisors gazed at those men and saw that the fire had no effect on their bodies—not a hair on their head was singed, their clothes were not burned, and they did not smell of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nebuchadnezzar spoke up and announced:
“Blessed be the God of Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego! He sent his angel to deliver his servants who trusted in him. They disobeyed the king’s command and were willing to risk their lives in order not to serve or worship any god except their own God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I decree that people from any nation or language who say anything against the God of Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego will be destroyed and their house reduced to rubble, because there is no other god who can save like this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego within the province of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An Official Statement
from Nebuchadnezzar
the King
To the people of all nations and languages who live on earth.
Peace and prosperity to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: It gives me great pleasure to tell about the signs and wonders that the Most High God has done for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How great are his signs!
How powerful are his wonders!
His kingdom is an eternal kingdom, and his dominion lasts from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Nebuchadnezzar, was resting in my home and prospering in my palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had a dream that made me afraid. The thoughts that went through my mind while in bed and the visions in my head terrified me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I gave an order to bring in all of the advisors of Babylon so they would tell me the interpretation of the dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the diviners, enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers came in, and I told them the dream. But they could not reveal its interpretation to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Daniel appeared before me. (He is called Belteshazzar, in accordance with the name of my god, and the spirit of the holy gods is within him.) I told him my dream:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Belteshazzar, chief of the diviners, since I know that the spirit of the holy gods is within you, and no mystery too difficult for you, explain to me the vision of my dream that I saw, along with its interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what I saw in the visions of my head while I was in bed: I was looking and—listen carefully!—I saw a tree in the middle of the earth, the height of which was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tree grew large, became strong, and its top reached the sky. It could be seen to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its foliage was beautiful, its fruit bountiful, and its food sufficient for everyone. The animals of the field found shade under it, the birds of the sky lived in its branches, and every creature was fed from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I saw in the visions of my head while I was in bed—and take careful notice!—I saw a holy observer descend from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He called out aloud:
‘Cut down the tree and cut off its branches. Strip off its foliage and scatter its fruit. Let the animals get out from under it, and let the birds leave its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, leave the stump and its roots in the ground, but bind it with iron and bronze in the field grass. Let him be drenched with dew from the sky, and let him graze with the animals in the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let his mind be changed from that of a man, and let him be given the mind of an animal until seven seasons of time pass by for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This order is announced by the observers, and the holy ones declare the verdict, so that the living may know that the Most High is sovereign over human kingdoms and grants them to whomever he desires, and he places the least important of men over them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the dream that I, King Nebuchadnezzar, saw. Belteshazzar, tell me its meaning, since none of the advisors in my kingdom can tell me its interpretation. But you are able to do so because the spirit of the holy gods is in you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Daniel (also known as Belteshazzar) was greatly troubled for a while and was terrified by his thoughts. The king said, “Belteshazzar, don’t let the dream or its meaning terrify you.”
Belteshazzar responded, “Your majesty, if only the dream were about your enemies and its meaning about those who oppose you!
speaker: Narrator

text: The tree that you saw, which grew large and strong until its top reached the sky and became visible to the whole earth
speaker: Narrator

text: with beautiful leaves and abundant fruit—enough food for everyone—and under which wild animals of the field found shelter and the birds of the air had nests in its branches—
speaker: Narrator

text: it’s you, your majesty! You’ve become great and strong, your greatness has grown to the heavens, and your dominion reaches to the distant parts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your majesty saw a holy observer descending from heaven and saying, ‘Cut down the tree and destroy it, but leave the stump in the ground, along with its roots, bound with iron and bronze in the field grass. Let him be soaked with the dew of the sky and live with the wild animals of the field until seven seasons pass over him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the meaning, your majesty, and this is the decree that the Most High has issued against his majesty, the king:
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll be driven from people, and you’ll live among wild animals of the field. You’ll eat grass like cattle and be soaked with the dew of the sky while seven years pass you by—until you realize that the Most High is sovereign over human kingdoms and grants them to whomever he desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as it was ordered to leave the stump of the tree in the ground along with its roots, so your kingdom will be restored to you when you realize that Heaven rules over everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, your majesty, may my advice be acceptable to you: Stop your sinning, do what’s right, and put a stop to your wickedness by showing kindness to the oppressed. Perhaps your tranquility will continue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All of this happened to King Nebuchadnezzar.
speaker: Narrator

text: About a year later, as the king was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon,
speaker: Narrator

text: he commented to himself, “Isn’t Babylon great? I’ve built a royal palace in it by my own might and power, for the sake of my majesty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As these words were being spoken by the king, a voice came out of heaven: “King Nebuchadnezzar, this is declared to you:
‘The kingdom has been taken from you!
speaker: Narrator

text: You’re to be driven away from people. You’re to live with the wild animals of the field. You are to be made to eat grass like cattle, and seven years will pass you by until you realize that the Most High is sovereign over human kingdoms and grants them to whomever he desires.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The decree was fulfilled against Nebuchadnezzar immediately. He was driven away from people to eat grass like cattle, and his body was drenched with dew from the sky, until his hair grew like eagles’ feathers and his nails like birds’ claws.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When that period of time was over, I, Nebuchadnezzar, lifted my eyes to heaven and my sanity returned to me. I blessed the Most High, praising and honoring the one who lives forever:
For his sovereignty is eternal,
    and his kingdom continues from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All who live on the earth
    are nothing compared to him.
He does what he wishes
    with the heavenly armies
        and with those who live on earth.
No one can hold back his power
    or say to him, ‘What did you do?’
speaker: Narrator

text: At that moment I recovered my sanity, and my honor and majesty returned to me, for the sake of my kingdom. My advisors and officials sought me out, my throne was restored, and even more greatness than I had before was added to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In conclusion, I, Nebuchadnezzar, praise, exalt, and give glory to the King of heaven:
For everything he does is true,
    his ways are just,
        and he is able to humble those who walk in pride.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Belshazzar put on a great festival for a thousand of his officials. He joined all one thousand of them in getting drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the influence of wine, Belshazzar ordered that the gold and silver vessels his grandfather Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the Temple in Jerusalem be brought in so the king, his officials, his wives, and his mistresses could drink from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As ordered, they brought in the gold vessels that had been taken from the sanctuary of God’s Temple in Jerusalem, and the king, his officials, his wives, and mistresses drank from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they drank the wine, they praised gods of gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that moment, humanlike fingers of a hand appeared near the lamp stand of the royal palace and wrote on the plaster of the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the king watched the back of the hand as it was writing, his facial expression changed. Utterly frightened, he lost control of his own bowels and his knees knocked together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king cried out to bring in enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers. He announced to the advisors of Babylon, “Whoever can read this writing and tell me its meaning will be clothed in purple, have a gold chain placed around his neck, and will become the third highest ruler in the kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the king’s advisors came in, but they were unable to read the writing or tell the king what it meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Belshazzar became even more frightened, and his facial expression showed it. His officials also were thrown into confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearing the voices of the king and his officials, the queen entered the banquet hall. “Your majesty, live forever,” the queen said. “Don’t be frightened by your thoughts or allow your facial expression to show it.
speaker: Narrator

text: There’s a man in your kingdom in whom dwells the spirit of the holy gods. During your grandfather’s reign, he was found to have insight, intelligence, and wisdom, like that of the gods. Your grandfather, King Nebuchadnezzar—your kingly predecessor—appointed him to be chief administrator over the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers,
speaker: Narrator

text: because he was found to have an extraordinary spirit, knowledge, and understanding, along with an ability to interpret dreams, explain riddles, and solve difficult problems. His name is Daniel, whom the king renamed Belteshazzar. Call for Daniel, and he will reveal the meaning of the writing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel was brought before the king. The king spoke up and told Daniel, “So you are Daniel, one of the Judean exiles whom my grandfather the king brought from Judah!
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve heard about you, that a spirit of the gods is in you and that you have insight, discernment, and extraordinary wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take note that the advisors and enchanters were brought before me to read the writing and explain its meaning, but they were unable to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I’ve heard that you can provide meaning and interpretation, and that you can solve difficult problems. If you are able to read the writing and report its meaning, you will be clothed in purple, have a gold chain placed around your neck, and you will become the third highest ruler in the kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Daniel answered, speaking directly to the king, “Let your gifts and rewards be given to someone else. However, I’ll read the writing for the king and tell him its meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your majesty, the Most High God gave your grandfather Nebuchadnezzar sovereignty, as well as greatness, glory, and splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because of the greatness that he gave him, all people, nations, and languages revered and feared him. He executed those whom he desired to execute, he spared those whom he wished to spare, he promoted those whom he desired to promote, and he humbled those whom he wished to humble.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he became arrogant and his spirit hardened, he was removed from his royal throne and his glory was taken away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was driven away from human society and given the mind of an animal. He lived with wild donkeys, ate grass like cattle, and his body was soaked with dew from the sky until he realized that the Most High God is sovereign over human kingdoms and places over them whomever he desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you, Belshazzar, his grandson, haven’t humbled yourself, even though you knew all of this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You’ve exalted yourself against the Lord of heaven.
“You’ve had the vessels from his Temple brought into your presence.
“And you, your officials, and your wives and mistresses drank wine from them.
“You praised gods of silver, gold, bronze, iron, wood, and stone, which can’t see, hear, or demonstrate knowledge.
“But you didn’t honor God, who holds in his power your very life and all your ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, the hand that wrote this inscription was sent from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the written inscription:
MENE, MENE, TEKEL and PARSIN
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the meanings of the words:
MENE: God has audited your kingdom—and has ended it.
speaker: Narrator

text: TEKEL: You’ve been weighed on the scales—and you don’t measure up.
speaker: Narrator

text: PERES: Your kingdom has been divided—and will be given to the Medes and Persians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Belshazzar gave orders to clothe Daniel in purple, to place a chain of gold around his neck, and to proclaim him the third highest ruler of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night Belshazzar, king of the Chaldeans, was killed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Darius the Mede took over the kingdom at the age of 62.
speaker: Narrator

text: It pleased Darius to appoint 120 regional authorities over the kingdom throughout the realm,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with three chief administrators from them, one of which was Daniel. The regional authorities reported to these three administrators, so that the king would experience no losses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel distinguished himself among all the administrators and regional authorities, because he was of an extraordinary spirit. Therefore the king planned to appoint him over the whole kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, the administrators and regional authorities tried to bring allegations of dereliction of duty in government affairs against Daniel, but they were unable to find any charges of corruption. Daniel was trustworthy, and no evidence of negligence or corruption could be found against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these men said, “We’ll never find any basis for complaint against Daniel unless we build it on the requirements of his God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then these administrators and regional authorities went as a group to the king and said this, “Your majesty, live forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the royal administrators, prefects, regional authorities, scribes, and governors have concluded that the king should establish and enforce an edict that anyone who prays to any god or man for the next 30 days (except to you, your majesty) is to be thrown into the lions’ pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, your majesty, establish the decree and sign the written document so it can’t be changed, in accordance with the laws of the Medes and Persians that can’t be repealed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Darius signed the edict contained in the written document.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Daniel learned that the written document had been signed, he went to an upstairs room in his house that had windows opened facing Jerusalem. Three times a day he would kneel down, pray, and give thanks to his God, just as he had previously done.
speaker: Narrator

text: The conspirators then went as a group and found Daniel praying and seeking help before his God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they approached the king and asked, “Didn’t you sign an edict that for the next 30 days if anyone prays to any god or man, except to you, your majesty, he would be thrown into the lions’ pit?”
The king responded, “The decree has been established, in accordance with the laws of the Medes and Persians that can’t be repealed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they told the king, “Daniel, who is one of the Judean exiles, pays no attention to you, your majesty, or to the written decree, since he is still praying three times a day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard this, he was greatly upset, because he was determined to make every effort to save Daniel before the sun set.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men who had gone as a group to the king told him, “Remember, your majesty, that according to the laws of the Medes and Persians, any decree or edict that the king establishes cannot be repealed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, the king ordered Daniel brought in and thrown into the lions’ pit. The king spoke to Daniel, “Your God, whom you serve constantly, will deliver you himself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A stone was brought and placed over the opening to the pit, and the king affixed a seal to it with his personal signet ring and with the signet rings of his officials so that no one would interfere with Daniel’s situation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king retired to his palace to spend the night fasting. He enjoyed no entertainment, and he couldn’t sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king got up at dawn and went quickly to the lions’ pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he approached where Daniel was in the pit, he cried out to him in a voice filled with anguish, “Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God, whom you serve constantly, been able to deliver you from the lions?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel replied to the king, “May your majesty live forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: My God sent his angel and sealed the mouths of the lions. They have not harmed me, proving that I’m innocent before him. Also against you, your majesty, I’ve committed no offense.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was ecstatic, so he gave orders for Daniel to be released from the pit. Daniel was taken up from the pit, and no injury was found to have been inflicted on him, because he had believed in his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king gave orders to bring those men who had tried to have Daniel devoured, and they threw them, their children, and their wives into the lions’ pit. They had not reached the floor of the pit before the lions had overtaken them and crushed all their bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Afterward, King Darius wrote to all people, nations, and languages who lived throughout his realm:
“May great prosperity be yours!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I hereby decree that in every area of my kingdom men are to fear and tremble before the God of Daniel.
For he is the living God,
    who endures forever.
His kingdom is one that will not be destroyed,
    and his dominion continues forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivers and rescues
    and performs signs and wonders
        in heaven and on earth.
He has delivered Daniel
    from the power of the lions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel achieved success during the reigns of Darius and Cyrus the Persian.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first year of the reign of King Belshazzar of Babylon, Daniel dreamed a dream, receiving visions in his mind while in bed, after which he recorded the dream, relating this summary of events.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel said, “I observed the vision during the night. Look! The four winds of the skies were stirring up the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Four magnificent animals were rising from the sea, each different from the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first resembled a lion, but it had eagles’ wings. I continued to watch until its wings were plucked off, it was lifted up off the ground, and it was forced to stand on two feet like a man. A human soul was imparted to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then look!—a second animal resembling a bear followed it. It was raised up on one side, with three ribs held between the teeth in its mouth. Therefore people kept telling it, ‘Get up and devour lots of meat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After this, I continued to watch—and look!—there was another one, resembling a leopard with four birds’ wings on its back. The animal also had four heads, and authority was imparted to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After this, I continued to observe the night visions. And look!—there was a fourth awe-inspiring, terrifying, and viciously strong animal! It had large, iron teeth. It devoured and crushed things, and trampled under its feet whatever remained. Different from all of the other previous animals, it had ten horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: “While I was thinking about the horns—look—another horn, this time a little one, grew up among them. Three of the first horns were yanked up by their roots right in front of it. Look! It had eyes like those of a human being and a mouth that boasted with audacious claims.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I kept on watching until the Ancient of Days was seated. His clothes were white, like snow, and the hair on his head was like pure wool. His throne burned with flaming fire, and its wheels burned with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: A river of fire flowed out from before him. Thousands upon thousands were serving him, with millions upon millions waiting before him. The court sat in judgment, and record books were unsealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I continued watching because of the audacious words that the horn was speaking. I kept observing until the animal was killed and its body destroyed and given over to burning fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to the other animals, their authority was removed, but they were granted a reprieve from execution for an appointed period of time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I continued to observe the night vision—and look!—someone like the Son of Man was coming, accompanied by heavenly clouds. He approached the Ancient of Days and was presented before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: To him dominion was bestowed, along with glory and a kingdom, so that all people, nations, and languages are to serve him. His dominion is an everlasting dominion—it will never pass away—and his kingdom is one that will never be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as for me, Daniel, I was emotionally troubled, and what I had seen in the visions kept alarming me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I approached one of those who was standing nearby and began to ask the meaning of all of this. He spoke to me and caused me to understand the interpretation of these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘These four great animals are four kings who will rise to power from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the saints of the Highest will receive the kingdom forever, inheriting it forever and ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I wanted to learn the precise significance of the fourth animal that was different from all the others, extremely awe-inspiring, with iron teeth and bronze claws, and that had devoured and crushed things, trampling under its feet whatever remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, I wanted to learn the significance of the ten horns on its head and the other horn that had arisen, before which three of them had fallen—that is, the horn with eyes and a mouth that uttered magnificent things and which was greater in appearance than its fellows.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I continued to watch, that same horn waged war against the saints, and was prevailing against them
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Ancient of Days arrived to pass judgment in favor of the saints of the Highest One and the time came for the saints to take possession of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he said:
‘The fourth animal will be a fourth kingdom on the earth, different from all the kingdoms. It will devour the entire earth, trampling it down and crushing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to the ten horns, ten kings will rise to power from this kingdom, and another king will rise to power after them. He will be different from the previous kings, and will defeat three kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll speak out against the Most High and wear down the saints of the Highest One. He’ll attempt to alter times and laws, and they’ll be given into his control for a time, times, and half a time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the court will convene, and his authority will be removed, annulled, and destroyed forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the kingdom, authority, and magnificence of all nations of the earth will be given to the people who are the saints of the Highest One. His kingdom will endure forever, and all authorities will serve him and obey him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At this point the vision ended. As for me, Daniel, my thoughts continued to alarm me, and I lost my natural color, but I kept quiet about the matter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “During the third year of King Belshazzar’s reign, I, Daniel, saw a vision after the earlier vision that had appeared to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I observed the vision, I looked around the citadel of Susa in Elam Province. While I watched, I found myself beside the Ulai Canal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I turned my head to look, and to my surprise, a two-horned ram was standing beside the canal. The two horns grew long, the first one growing longer than the second, with the longer one springing up last.
speaker: Narrator

text: I watched the ram charging westward, northward, and southward. No animal could stand before him, nor was there anyone who could deliver from his control. He did as he pleased and exalted himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I watched and wondered, a male goat was coming from the west over the surface of the entire earth without touching the ground. The goat had a distinctive horn between its eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: It approached the ram with the two horns that I had observed while standing beside the canal, and charged at him, out of control with rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw it approach the ram, overflowing with fury at him, and run into him with the full force of its strength. The goat shattered the ram’s two horns, and the ram could not oppose it. So the goat threw him to the ground and trampled him. No one could rescue the ram from its control.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the goat grew extremely great, but when it was strong, its great horn was shattered. In its place, four distinctive horns grew out in all directions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “A somewhat insignificant horn emerged from one of them. It moved rapidly against the south, against the east, and against the Glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it moved against the Heavenly Army. It persuaded some of the Heavenly Army to fall to the earth, along with some of the stars, and it trampled them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it set itself in arrogant opposition to the Prince of the Heavenly Army, from whom the regular burnt offering was taken away, in order to overthrow his sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the transgression, the Heavenly Army will be given over, along with the regular burnt offering, and in that rebellion truth will be cast to the ground, while he continues to prosper and to act.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I heard one holy person speaking, and another holy person addressed the one who was speaking: ‘In the vision about the regular burnt offering, how much time elapses while the desecration terrifies and both the Holy Place and the Heavenly Army are trampled?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He told me, ‘For 2,300 days. Then the Holy Place will be restored.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “After I, Daniel, had seen the vision, I tried to understand it. All of a sudden, there was standing in front of me one who appeared to be valiant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard the voice of a man calling out from the Ulai Canal, ‘Gabriel, interpret what that fellow has been seeing.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As he approached where I was standing, I became terrified and fell on my face. But he told me, ‘Son of man, understand that the vision pertains to the time of the end.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “While he had been speaking with me, I had fainted on my face, but he touched me and enabled me to stand upright on my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said,
‘Pay attention! I’m going to brief you about what will happen at the end of the period of wrath, because its end is appointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ram that you saw with a pair of horns are the kings of Media and Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: The demonic goat is the king of Greece, and the great horn between its eyes is its first king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shattered horn and the four that took its place are four kingdoms that will come from his nation, but they will not have his strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Toward the end of their rule, as the desecrations proceed, an insolent king will arise, proficient at deception.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mighty will be his skills, but not from his own abilities. He’ll be remarkably destructive, will succeed, and will do whatever he wants, destroying mighty men and the holy people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through his skill he’ll cause deceit to prosper under his leadership. He’ll promote himself and will destroy many while they are secure. He’ll take a stand against the Prince of Princes, yet he’ll be crushed without human help.
speaker: Narrator

text: The vision about the twilights and dawnings that has been related is trustworthy, but keep its vision secret, because it pertains to the distant future.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I, Daniel, was exhausted and ill for days, but afterward I got up and went about the king’s business. Nevertheless, I was astonished by the vision, and could not understand it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the first year of the reign of Darius son of Ahasuerus, a descendant of the Medes, who was made king over the kingdom of the Chaldeans—
speaker: Narrator

text: in the first year of his reign I, Daniel, noted in the Scripture the total years that were assigned by the message from the Lord to Jeremiah the prophet for the completion of the desolations of Jerusalem: 70 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I turned my attention to the Lord God, seeking him in prayer and supplication, accompanied with fasting, sackcloth, and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I prayed to the Lord my God, confessing and saying:
‘Lord! Great and awesome God, who keeps his covenant and gracious love for those who love him and obey his commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text: we’ve sinned, we’ve practiced evil, we’ve acted wickedly, and we’ve rebelled, turning away from your commands and from your regulations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, we haven’t listened to your servants, the prophets, who spoke in your name to our kings, to our officials, to our ancestors, and to all of the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘To you, Lord, belongs righteousness, but to us, open humiliation—even to this day, to the men of Judah, the residents of Jerusalem, and to all Israel, both those who are nearby and those who are far away in all the lands to which you drove them because of their unfaithful acts that they committed against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Open humiliation belongs to us, Lord, to our kings, our officials, and our ancestors, because we’ve sinned against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the Lord our God belong mercy and forgiveness, though we’ve rebelled against him
speaker: Narrator

text: and have not obeyed the voice of the Lord our God by walking in his laws that he gave us through his servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all Israel flouted your Law, turning aside from it and not obeying your voice. Because we’ve sinned against him, the curse has been poured upon us, along with the oath written in the Law of Moses the servant of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘He has confirmed his accusation that he spoke against us and against our rulers who governed us by bringing upon us great calamity, because nowhere in the universe has anything been done like what has been done to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it’s written in the Law of Moses, all this calamity has befallen us, but we still haven’t sought the Lord our God by turning from our lawlessness to pay attention to your truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord watched for the right time to bring the calamity upon us, because the Lord our God is righteous regarding everything he does, but we have not obeyed his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘And now, Lord our God, who brought your people from the land of Egypt with a mighty hand and who made a name for yourself that remains to this day—we’ve sinned. We’ve acted wickedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lord, in view of all your righteous acts, please turn your anger and wrath away from your city Jerusalem, your holy mountain. Because of our sins and the iniquities of our ancestors, Jerusalem and your people have become an embarrassment to all of those around us.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So now, O God, listen to the prayer of your servant and to his requests, and look with favor on your desolate sanctuary, for the sake of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn your ear and listen, O God. Open your eyes and look at our desolation and at the city that is called by your name. We’re not presenting our requests before you because of our righteousness, but because of your great compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Lord, listen!
‘Lord, forgive!
‘Lord, take note and take action!
‘For your own sake, don’t delay, my God, because your city and your people are called by your name.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “While I was still speaking in prayer, confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel and placing my request in the presence of the Lord my God on behalf of the holy mountain of God—
speaker: Narrator

text: while I was still speaking, Gabriel, the man of God whom I had seen in the previous vision, appeared to me about the time of the evening offering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave instructions, and this is what he spoke to me:
‘Daniel, I’ve now come to give you insight and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you’re highly regarded, the answer was issued when you began your prayer, and I’ve come to tell you. Pay attention to my message and you’ll understand the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seventy weeks have been decreed concerning your people and your holy city: to restrain transgression, to put an end to sin, to make atonement for lawlessness, to establish everlasting righteousness, to conclude vision and prophecy, and to anoint the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be informed and discern that seven weeks and 62 weeks will elapse from the issuance of the command to restore and rebuild Jerusalem until the Anointed Commander. The plaza and moat will be rebuilt, though in troubled times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then after the 62 weeks, the anointed one will be cut down (but not for himself). Then the people of the Coming Commander will destroy both the city and the Sanctuary. Its ending will come like a flood, and until the end there will be war, with desolations having been decreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will make a binding covenant with many for one week, and for half of the week he will suspend both the sacrifice and grain offerings. Destructive people will cause desolation on the uttermost edge of the Sanctuary until it is complete and what has been decreed is poured out on the desolator.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of Cyrus, king of Persia, a message was revealed to Daniel (also known as Belteshazzar). The message was trustworthy and concerned a great conflict. He understood it and had insight concerning the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I, Daniel, had been mourning for three straight weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: I ate no fancy foods—neither meat nor wine entered my mouth. Furthermore, I didn’t use any ointment until the end of the entire three weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-fourth day of the first month, while I was beside the bank of the great Tigris River,
speaker: Narrator

text: I lifted up my eyes to look, and to my surprise, there was a certain man dressed in linen, whose waist was encircled with gold from Uphaz!
speaker: Narrator

text: His body was like beryl, his face flashed like lightning, his eyes were like flaming torches, his arms and legs were like polished bronze, and his speech roared like that of a crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now I, Daniel, was the only one to receive the vision—the men who were with me didn’t see it. However, an enormous fear overwhelmed them, so they ran away to hide,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I was left alone to observe this magnificent vision. Nevertheless, no strength remained in me—my face lost its color, and I became weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I listened to the sound of his words, I fell down on my face unconscious, with my face to the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All of a sudden, a hand touched me and lifted me upon my hands and knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told me, ‘Daniel, man highly regarded, understand the message that I’m about to relate to you. Stand up, because I’ve been sent to you.’ When he spoke this statement to me, I stood there trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Don’t be afraid, Daniel,’ he told me, ‘because from the first day that you committed yourself to understand and to humble yourself before your God, your words were heard. I’ve come in answer to your prayers.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the prince of the kingdom of Persia opposed me for 21 days. Then all of a sudden, Michael, one of the chief angels, came to assist me! I had been detained there near the kings of Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I’ve come to help you understand what will happen to your people in the days to come, because the vision pertains to those days.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After he had spoken to me like this, I bowed my face to the ground, unable to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suddenly someone who resembled a human being touched my lips, so addressing the one who was standing in front of me, I opened my mouth and said, ‘Sir, I’m overwhelmed with anguish by this vision. I have no strength left.
speaker: Narrator

text: So how can a servant of my lord talk with someone like you, sir? And as for me, there’s no strength left in me, and I can hardly breathe.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then this person who looked like a man touched me again and strengthened me
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, ‘Don’t be afraid, man highly regarded. Be at peace, and be strong.’
“As soon as he spoke to me, I gained strength and replied, ‘Sir, please speak, now that you’ve strengthened me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said, ‘Do you understand why I came to you? Soon I’ll return to fight the prince of Persia. I’m going forth to war—and take note—the prince of Greece is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll inform you about what has been recorded in the Book of Truth. No one stands firmly with me against these opponents, except Michael your prince.
speaker: Narrator

text: In year one of King Darius the Mede, I arose to fortify and strengthen him.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now I’ll tell you the truth: Pay attention! Three more kings will arise in Persia. Then a fourth will gain more than them all. As soon as he gains power by means of his wealth, he’ll stir up everyone against the Grecian kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘A mighty king will come to power, and he’ll rule with awesome energy, doing whatever he pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, after he has come to power, his kingdom will be broken and parceled out in all directions. It won’t go to his succeeding descendants, nor will its power match how he ruled, because his sovereignty will be uprooted and given to successors besides them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The southern king will become strong, along with one of his officials, who will become stronger than he and rule over his own realm with great power.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a number of years, they’ll become allies and the daughter of the southern king will go to the northern king in order to craft alliances. But she won’t remain in power, nor will he retain his power. Instead, she’ll be surrendered, along with her entourage, the one who fathered her, and the one who supported her at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘One of her family line will replace him. He’ll come against the army and enter the fortress of the northern king, conquering them and becoming victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll also take their gods, their molten images, and their valuable vessels of silver and gold into Egypt as hostages. He’ll avoid the northern king for a number of years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he’ll come against the realm of the southern king and then return to his own territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons will prepare for war, assembling an army of considerable force. One of them will come on forcefully, overflowing, passing through, and waging war up to his own fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The southern king will fly into a rage and march out to fight the northern king. He’ll gather a large army, but that army will be handed over to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that army has been defeated, he’ll become overconfident and slaughter many thousands, but he won’t succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The northern king will return and raise a greater army than before. After a few years, he’ll advance with a great force and with a vast amount of armaments.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘During those years, many will rebel against the southern king. The more violent ones among your people will rebel in order to fulfill this vision, but they will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the northern king will come, erect a siege ramp, and capture a fortified city. The southern forces won’t prevail—not even with their best troops—and they’ll have no strength to take a stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘However, the one who invades him will do whatever he wants to do. No one will oppose him. He’ll establish himself in the Beautiful Land, wielding devastating power.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll decide to come with the full power of his kingdom, bringing with him an alliance that he’ll implement. He’ll give him a daughter in marriage to overthrow it, but it won’t succeed or work out for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he’ll turn his attention to the coastal lands and will capture many. But a commander will put an end to his insolence, repaying him for his scorn.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll turn his attention toward the fortresses in his own territory, but he’ll stumble and fall, and won’t endure.
speaker: Narrator

text: His successor will send out a tax collector for royal splendor, but in a short period of time he’ll be shattered, though neither in anger nor in battle.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘In his place there will arise a despicable person, upon whom no royal authority has been conferred, but he’ll invade in a time of tranquility, taking over the kingdom through deception.
speaker: Narrator

text: Overwhelming forces will be carried away before him, along with the Commander-in-Chief of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the time that an alliance is made with him, he’ll act deceitfully, and he will go up and take power with only a small group of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll invade the most prosperous areas of the province during a time of tranquility, accomplishing what neither his predecessors nor his ancestors ever could. He’ll distribute war spoils, booty, and wealth to them, and he’ll plot the overthrow of fortresses, though only for a time.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll encourage himself against the southern king by raising a large army. As a result, the southern king will mobilize for war with a large and powerful army, but he won’t succeed because they will devise elaborate schemes against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His own security detail will undermine him, his army will be swept away, and many will fall and be killed in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for the two kings, their intentions will be evil, and they’ll promote deception at their dinner table, but none of this will succeed, because the end won’t have come yet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he’ll return to his homeland with great wealth, will focus his attention against the holy covenant, and will take action as he returns to his land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘At the scheduled time he’ll return, moving southward, but the end result won’t be as before,
speaker: Narrator

text: because ships will come against him from the Mediterranean islands. Disheartened, he’ll return, incited to vehemence against the holy covenant, and he’ll take action. As he returns, he’ll show deference to those who abandon the holy covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Armed forces will arise from his midst, and they’ll desecrate the fortified Sanctuary, abolish the daily sacrifice, and establish the destructive desecration.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through flattery he’ll corrupt those who act wickedly toward the covenant, but people who know their God will be strong and take action.
speaker: Narrator

text: Insightful people will impart understanding to many, though they’ll fall by sword, by fire, by captivity, and as war booty for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they fall, they’ll be given some relief, but many will join them by pretending to be sympathetic to their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the insightful will fall so they may be refined, purged, and purified until the time of the end, since it will surely come about.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The king will do as he pleases. He’ll exalt and magnify himself above every god, speaking amazing things against the God of Gods. He’ll succeed until the indignation is completed, because what has been determined must be carried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll recognize neither the gods of his ancestors nor those desired by women—he won’t recognize any god, because he’ll exalt himself above everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll glorify the god of fortresses, a god whom his ancestors never knew, honoring him with gold, silver, valuable jewels, and treasures.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll take action against the strongest fortresses. With the help of a foreign god, he’ll recognize those who honor him, making them rule over many, and he’ll parcel out the land for a profit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘At the time of the end, the southern king will oppose him, and the northern king will overrun him with chariots, cavalry, and many ships. He’ll invade countries, moving swiftly and sweeping through.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll enter the Beautiful Land, and many will fall, even though these will escape his control: Edom, Moab, and certain Ammonite officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll extend his power over other countries, and even the land of Egypt won’t escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll capture treasures of gold, silver, and all the treasures of Egypt, with the Libyans and Cushites at his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, reports from the east and the north will alarm him, and he’ll march out in great anger, intending to destroy and to desolate many.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he pitches his royal pavilions between the seas facing the mountain of holy Glory, he’ll come to his end, and no one will help him.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘At that time, Michael will arise, the great prince who will stand up on behalf of your people, and a time of trouble will come like there has never been since nations began until that time. Also at that time, your people will be delivered—everyone who will have been written in the book.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of those who are sleeping in the dust of the earth will awaken—some to life everlasting, and some to disgrace and everlasting contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who manifest wisdom will shine like the brightness of the expanse of heaven, and those who turn many to righteousness will shine like the stars for ever and ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for you, Daniel, roll up your scroll and seal your words until the time of the end. Many will rush around, while knowledge increases.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then while I, Daniel, continued watching, suddenly two others stood there, one on this side of the river bank and one on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: One asked the man dressed in linen clothes, who was standing above the waters of the river, ‘How long until the fulfillment of the wonders?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I heard the man dressed in linen clothes, who was standing above the waters of the river as he lifted his right and left hands to heaven and swore by the one who lives forever that it would be for a time, times, and a half. When the shattering of the power of the holy people has occurred, all these things will conclude.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I heard, but I didn’t understand. So I asked, ‘Sir, what happens next?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He answered, ‘Go on your way, Daniel, because these matters are wrapped up and sealed until the time of the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many will be purified, cleansed, and refined, though the wicked will continue to act wickedly, and none of the wicked will understand. Nevertheless, the insightful will understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be 1,290 days from the time the regular burnt offering is rescinded and the destructive desolation established.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is the one who perseveres and attains to the 1,335 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for you, keep on going until the end—you’ll rest and then rise to receive your reward at the end of the age.’”
speaker: Narrator
